page.title: 17COPPICING, ANGMERING PARK
page.content: In ancient England, when wood was used for many things, people invented a system of forestry called coppicing to keep up the supply. In Angmering Woods, now leased to the Forestry Commision, the original copses are still clearly laid out. Oak and hazel were grown. The tops of the oak were cut till there was only a trunk. This was called pollarding. The oak then sprouted thick branches from the top used for fuel, house beams and ships. The hazels were cut down to the ground so they grew thin sprouts for uses like Sussex hurdle fences. This is coppicing. Most of the woodland was planted about 100 to 300 years ago although Buckman's Coppice and Poling Coppice are mentioned in a document of 1679. The older copses have wavy boundaries whilst those planted after 1700 have straight ones.
